description: From Middle English *ofhande, *ofhende, from Old English ofhende (“absent, lost”), ultimately from Proto-Germanic *abahandijaz. Equivalent to off- +‎ hand. Cognate with Icelandic afhendur. Compare onhand.

adjectives.description: offhand (comparative more offhand, superlative most offhand)

entries.meaning: Careless; without sufficient thought or consideration.
examples: He doesn't realise how hurtful his offhand remarks can be.
She was quite offhand with me yesterday.

adverbs.description: offhand (comparative more offhand, superlative most offhand)

entries.meaning: Right away, immediately, without thinking about it.
examples: We will have no more of this shilly-shallying! Call the Archbishop, and let the Prince and Princess be married offhand!
